title: Can a person be named executor if he is a drug user? Methamphetamine, marijuana....
question: My fathers brother wants to be named co executor of their sisters estate. He is a theif, liar and a heavy drug user. Is there a law that will prevent him this title of executor because of his drug problem?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Marijuana laws and criminal charges,Criminal charges for forgery,Wills and estates,Estates,Wills,Forged will,Executor of will,Probate,Probate court,Lawsuits and disputes
answers:
The executor- is the person selected by the testator to administer his estate, gathering assets, paying debts and disbursing estate property according to the terms of the will. If an heir challenges the appointment of an executor, the court sets trial on the issues raised. A court can remove executors for failure to fulfill the duties of office. The appointment of an executor can also fail if the will appointing her is void or invalid.

For you to challenge, you must have standing - be an "interested" person - a person who inherits under the will currently in probate or who stands to inherit if the current will is invalidated. A close relationship with the deceased, by itself, does not confer standing.

Make sure the executor was actually named in the will - a simple reading of the will should be sufficient. The most straightforward challenges to an executor are proof that the testator did not appoint her or proof that the will appointing her was forged, improperly witnessed or otherwise invalid.

There may be grounds for challenging the executor. An executor is one of a a position of trust to the testator's heirs; the law imposes the highest possible duty on an executor, termed a fiduciary duty.

The executor's duty requires that he or she take whatever action is necessary to ensure that the beneficiaries of the will receive maximum benefits. There can be no self-dealing or dishonesty. Consider whether evidence establishes that the executor is UNFIT to undertake that duty or that she has failed to perform that duty; drug use and criminal activity may render him unfit.

Make/file a TIMELY objection to the will (or to the executor) with the probate court. After receiving an objection, the court sets a trial date for each side to present evidence. Prepare your case and present your arguments. Be convincing. The court either rules may rule mmediately after trial or, more likely, takes the matter under advisement and mails a written decision to the parties at a later date.

This is legal information, not legal advice.

Consult with a lawyer admitted to practice in California.
